explanation: The claim is correct: the assignment addrlen = 0 in the RemoteAddr == NULL branch is redundant and can be removed without changing the program behaviour as shown. In this function addrlen is only used in two places: (1) it is passed by address to recvfrom() and (2) it is copied back into RemoteAddr->ActualLength only when RemoteAddr != NULL. When RemoteAddr == NULL the code sets sa = NULL and later calls recvfrom(…, sa, &addrlen). POSIX semantics state that when addr is NULL the addrlen parameter is ignored, so the initial value written into addrlen before the call is never observed. In the other branch (RemoteAddr != NULL) addrlen is explicitly set to OS_SOCKADDR_MAX_LEN before the call. Therefore the write addrlen = 0 is executed but has no effect on any later behavior and is dead code under MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2. (Minor caveat: this conclusion relies on the expected semantics of the used recvfrom implementation — if a non-POSIX/buggy recvfrom were to read addrlen even when addr is NULL then removing the assignment could change behaviour. Under the usual POSIX semantics used here, the agent’s report is valid.)
